column1: Are booster shot side effects worse than those from the second shot?
column3: Booster side effects are not worse than the second shot
column4: People report that booster side effects are similar to those after the 2-dose series, mainly citing fatigue and pain at the injection site. 🩹 <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html">

column1: Are booster shot side effects worse than those from the second shot?
column3: Booster side effects are not worse than the second shot
column4: While people report more intense side effects after the second shot, side effects after your booster shot should be similar to the ones experienced after your first or second dose. 🩹

column1: Are booster shot side effects worse than those from the second shot?
column3: Booster side effects are not worse than the second shot
column4: It's normal to feel concerned about side effects. They should be similar to those you experienced after your first round of vaccination. Remember, side effects are normal signs that your body is building protection and should go away within a few days! 🤲

column1: Are children under 5 eligible for a vaccine?
column3: Children under 5 are eligible for a vaccine
column4: Children under 5 are now eligible for COVID-19 vaccines ✅! The FDA authorized and the CDC recommended COVID-19 vaccines for children as young as 6 months old after carefully evaluating the safety and efficacy data of the vaccines in children under 5 years. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are now available for children 6 months and older. Learn more about recommendations < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children”>

column1: Are children under 5 eligible for a vaccine?
column3: Children under 5 are eligible for a vaccine
column4: The vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna have been authorized by the FDA and recommended by the CDC for kids 6 months and above 👶✅. The vaccines are safe and significantly reduce the risk of severe disease and hospitalization in the case of COVID-19 disease in children. Learn more about recommendations < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children”>

column1: Are children under 5 eligible for a vaccine?
column3: Children under 5 are eligible for a vaccine
column4: Yes, children as young as 6 months old can now get the COVID-19 vaccine 👶✅! The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have been authorized by the FDA and recommended by the CDC for different age groups of children. The Pfizer vaccine has three shots in its series for children 6 months – 4 years and the Moderna vaccine has two shots in its series for children 6 months – 17 years. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children”>

column1: Are regular safety measures enough to stay healthy?
column2: I can avoid COVID-19 without the vaccine
column3: Vaccines are a tool to add to other measures
column4: Wearing masks😷, social distancing🧍▫️▫️🧍, & washing your hands🧼 are all really important! But even if you follow all these measures, you could still catch COVID-19. Vaccination is the best protection we have against the disease.

column1: Are regular safety measures enough to stay healthy?
column2: I can avoid COVID-19 without the vaccine
column3: Vaccines are a tool to add to other measures
column4: While masks 😷 & social distancing🧍▫️▫️🧍 help reduce your chance of being exposed or spreading the virus, vaccines boost your immune system to help you fight the virus 🦠.

column1: Are regular safety measures enough to stay healthy?
column2: I can avoid COVID-19 without the vaccine
column3: Vaccines are a tool to add to other measures
column4: A vaccine is necessary to help you and your community get back to normal. Stopping a COVID-19 infection requires using all the tools available - including vaccines and, when necessary, masks 😷 and social distancing🧍▫️▫️🧍.

column1: Are some vaccines safer for younger children than others?
column3: All authorized vaccines are safe for everyone 6 months of age
column4: The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are the only vaccines recommended by the CDC children 6 months and older. Experts agree that both vaccines provide children sufficient protection against severe disease. <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html">

column1: Are some vaccines safer for younger children than others?
column3: All authorized vaccines are safe for everyone 6 months of age
column4: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines  (and boosters!) are recommended by the CDC for children 6 months and older and are both safe and effective ✅. <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html">

column1: Are some vaccines safer for younger children than others?
column3: All authorized vaccines are safe for everyone 6 months of age
column4: The Pfizer and Moderna vaccine are the only vaccines available for children (6 months and older) and they are very safe ✅. Families can get children vaccinated to reduce the risk of severe illness 🙏 in the event of COVID-19 disease. <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.statnews.com/2022/05/27/jeremy-faust-interview-covid-vaccine-kids-under-5/">

column1: Are the rapid, at-home tests accurate?
column3: At-home tests are useful
column4: If a person has recently been exposed to another with COVID-19, or if they have symptoms of COVID-19 😷, the rapid home tests are useful in finding infection. This can help slow the spread of the virus, protecting us all! 💜 🙏 Learn more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/testing-overview.html">

column1: Are the rapid, at-home tests accurate?
column3: At-home tests are useful
column4: Testing is a great way to curb infection and protect our communities 💜. Rapid at-home tests are helpful with detecting COVID-19 for infected individuals who have symptoms. They may not be as accurate for those who do not have symptoms. Learn more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/testing-overview.html">

column1: Are the rapid, at-home tests accurate?
column3: At-home tests are useful
column4: Rapid at-home tests are a great way to check your infection status and protect your community 🏥✅ . These tests are cheaper and take less time than traditional testing but can give a false negative for individuals have COVID but do not have symptoms. Learn more <LINK | “here.” | ""https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/testing-overview.html""> "

column1: Are the side effects worse for the second shot
column2: Are side effects worse after second dose
column3: Yes, side effects can be much greater after the second shot
column4: Based on both clinical trials and anecdotal reports, the side effects can be more dramatic after the second dose or a booster dose🩹. Such side effects can last a few days, but it's a sign that your immune system is working correctly ✅! <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html" >

column1: Are the side effects worse for the second shot
column2: Are side effects worse after second dose
column3: Yes, side effects can be much greater after the second shot
column4: Many people have felt side effects of the second dose or a booster dose much more. The good news is side effects should go away in a day or two! While they are unpleasant, these effects show that your body is reacting correctly by creating antibodies to fight the virus🦠.  <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html" >

column1: Are the side effects worse for the second shot
column2: Are side effects worse after second dose
column3: Yes, side effects can be much greater after the second shot
column4: The symptoms after the second shot or a booster dose could mimic the effects of a bad flu, but this means your immune system is working properly to respond to the virus🦠 . These symptoms should go away in a day or two. <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html" >

column1: Are there medical contraindications to the vaccines?
column3: People with severe allergic reactions should talk to their healthcare provider before getting vaccinated
column4: The only contraindications are if you have an allergic reaction of any severity to a previous dose of the COVID-19 vaccine or a diagnosed allergy to any component of the vaccine. If so, you should talk to your healthcare provider prior to getting vaccinated 🩹✔.

column1: Are there medical contraindications to the vaccines?
column3: People with severe allergic reactions should talk to their healthcare provider before getting vaccinated
column4: Any severe allergic reaction to a previous dose or to an ingredient in the COVID-19 vaccines is considered a contraindication by the CDC. You should discuss this information with your healthcare provider prior to making any decisions about getting vaccinated🩹✔!

column1: Are women more likely to get worse side effects than men?
column3: Women have a higher immune response to vaccines
column4: Women are likely to get worse side effects than men. In general, they have a greater immune response to vaccines🦠 🩹, which helps explain their more frequent reporting of vaccine side effects. <LINK | "Learn more here!" | "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2021/04/10/covid-vaccine-women-report-more-side-effects-than-men-heres-why/7139366002/" >

column1: Are women more likely to get worse side effects than men?
column3: Women have a higher immune response to vaccines
column4: Women are more likely to get worse side effects than men, but only because women's bodies produce a greater immune response to the vaccine 🩹✔. <LINK | "Learn here." | "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2021/04/10/covid-vaccine-women-report-more-side-effects-than-men-heres-why/7139366002/">

column1: Are women more likely to get worse side effects than men?
column3: Women have a higher immune response to vaccines
column4: Women's bodies are powerful, so they tend to have a greater immune response to the vaccine 🦠 🩹! Unfortunately, that also means they're more likely to experience symptoms. (Boo!)

column1: Can children get the vaccine?
column3: Some kids are eligible for the vaccine
column4: The vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna are recommended by the CDC and authorized by the FDA for use in children above the age of 6 months. Updated (bivalent) booster vaccines are also available for kids 6+ months.  🙏🌞 . <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children">

column1: Can children get the vaccine?
column3: Some kids are eligible for the vaccine
column4: Children 6 months and older can get vaccinated and boosted. Thousands of children have been hospitalized due to COVID-19, so it's important to get your children vaccinated ASAP 🙏. This protects your children, your family, and your community from COVID-19💜. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children">

column1: Can children get the vaccine?
column3: Some kids are eligible for the vaccine
column4: Right now, the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are available for children 6 months and older, and updated (bivalent) boosters are also available for this age group! 🙏🌞. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html#children">

column1: Can I get a second dose even after a COVID exposure?
column3: If exposed, quarantine before getting a second shot
column4: COVID-19 exposure after the first dose does not affect an individual’s ability to get the second dose. An exposed individual needs to have completed the quarantine period following exposure, prior to coming to clinic for the 2nd dose ✔.

column1: Can I get a second dose even after a COVID exposure?
column3: If exposed, quarantine before getting a second shot
column4: You can’t get coronavirus from the vaccine. A vaccine would not be approved for use if it could give you the disease it is supposed to protect you from🤔. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/facts.html">

column1: Can I get a second dose even after a COVID exposure?
column3: If exposed, quarantine before getting a second shot
column4: You should still get the second dose of vaccine. If you were exposed to the virus you should quarantine before coming into the clinic ✔.

column1: Can I get COVID-19 from the vaccine?
column2: Concerned the vaccine will make me sick
column3: You cannot get COVID from the vaccine
column4: COVID-19 vaccines cannot cause COVID-19 disease. COVID-19 can have serious, life-threatening complications. If you get sick, you could spread the disease to friends, family, and others around you💜. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/facts.html">

column1: Can I get COVID-19 from the vaccine?
column2: Concerned the vaccine will make me sick
column3: You cannot get COVID from the vaccine
column4: The vaccines cannot give someone COVID-19. mRNA vaccines do not use the live viruses🦠 that causes COVID-19. Similarly, the Johnson & Johnson and the Novavax vaccines do not contain the live-virus, meaning you cannot get COVID-19 from the vaccines✅  . <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/facts.html">

column1: Can I get COVID-19 twice?
column3: You can get COVID-19 more than once
column4: With the arrival of new variants of SARS-CoV-2 🦠, the possibility of reinfection has increased. Immunity from previous infection wanes over time and may not be sufficient to fight off a different variant of the virus. The best way to protect yourself and others against the virus and its variants is to get your vaccination and booster shots. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/reinfection.html">

column1: Can I get COVID-19 twice?
column3: You can get COVID-19 more than once
column4: It’s very possible to get COVID-19 twice (or more). This is why it’s so important to get vaccinated! Booster shots are also available to individuals in the US who are 5 years and older. Until you're vaccinated, wear your mask 😷 and practice social distancing🧍▫️▫️🧍. The CDC also recommends masking up 😷 in areas with substantial risk of transmission, regardless of which vaccine you got and your vaccination status.<LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/reinfection.html">

column1: Can I get other vaccines at the same time?
column3: You can get other vaccines at the same time
column4: COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines🩹, including your flu shot, can be administered at the same time ✅. < LINK | "Read more from the CDC" | "https://www.cdc.gov/flu/prevent/coadministration.htm" > or check with your provider to learn more!

column1: Can I get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine?
column3: You can get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine
column4: People may get swollen lymph nodes after a vaccine. But this is fairly normal, as it is a sign that your immune system is reacting to the vaccine.🤔  <LINK | "Read more here!" | "https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/vaccine-reactions">

column1: Can I get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine?
column3: You can get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine
column4: People can get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine. The lymph nodes are home to the immune system, so swollen lymph nodes indicate that the immune system is reacting to the vaccine, as it should. 👏 <LINK | "Read more here!" | "https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/vaccine-reactions">

column1: Can I get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine?
column3: You can get swollen lymph nodes from the vaccine
column4: It is normal to feel swollen lymph nodes after receiving the vaccine, as they indicate the immune system mounting a response to the vaccine. This is normal and means the immune system is working. <LINK | "Learn more here." | "https://health.clevelandclinic.org/dont-be-alarmed-by-this-covid-19-vaccine-side-effect-that-could-be-confused-with-breast-cancer/">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have allergies?
column3: Vaccines are safe for people with most allergies
column4: If you're not sure or you have had a reaction to other vaccines, you should talk to healthcare provider first ✅. But allergic reactions to the COVID-19 vaccine are very rare! <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have allergies?
column3: Vaccines are safe for people with most allergies
column4: You should talk to your health provider if you have ever had an allergic reaction to a vaccine or vaccine ingredients , but severe allergic reactions to COVID vaccines are very rare! It's safe to get the vaccine if you have other allergies ✅. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have allergies?
column3: Vaccines are safe for people with most allergies
column4: The vaccines are safe for people with severe seasonal, pet, food, or oral medication allergies according to the CDC ✅. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have allergies?
column3: Vaccines are safe for people with most allergies
column4: The CDC recommends getting a COVID vaccine even if you have had a severe allergic reaction to oral medication, food, pets, venom, environment, or latex ✅.  <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have had allergic reactions to vaccines before?
column3: Talk to your doctor if you've had an allergic reaction to a vaccine before
column4: If you have had an immediate allergic reaction to a vaccine or injectable therapy for another disease—even if it was not severe—ask your doctor if you should get a COVID-19 vaccine ✅  . <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have had allergic reactions to vaccines before?
column3: Talk to your doctor if you've had an allergic reaction to a vaccine before
column4: It’s recommended that if you’ve had an allergic reaction to other vaccines or a severe allergic reaction to any of the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines, you should speak with your healthcare provider before getting vaccinated ✅ . Overall, having allergies doesn’t exclude you from getting the vaccine. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/specific-groups/allergies.html?s_cid=10480:covid%20vaccine%20allergy:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21">

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have Multiple Sclerosis?
column3: People with MS should get the vaccine
column4: Doctors recommend that people with Multiple Sclerosis get vaccinated against COVID-19. The vaccine is safe, effective, and the risks of COVID-19 disease are far greater than any potential risks from the vaccine for those with MS.  🤔 <LINK | “Check out their guidance.” | “https://www.nationalmssociety.org/coronavirus-covid-19-information/multiple-sclerosis-and-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-guidance”>

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have Multiple Sclerosis?
column3: People with MS should get the vaccine

column1: Can I get the vaccine if I have Multiple Sclerosis?
column3: People with MS should get the vaccine
column4: The National Multiple Sclerosis Society recommends COVID-19 vaccination for those with MS, but people should speak to your doctor if they have questions or concerns regarding vaccination.🤔  <LINK | “Check out the guidance.” | “https://www.nationalmssociety.org/coronavirus-covid-19-information/multiple-sclerosis-and-coronavirus/covid-19-vaccine-guidance”>

column1: Can I have the vaccine as a Catholic?
column3: The vaccine is approved by the Catholic church
column4: "I believe that morally everyone must take the vaccine," Pope Francis said in a Jan. 10 interview. "It is the moral choice because it is about your life but also the lives of others."💜 🙏  <LINK | "Read more from the interview." | "https://www.ncronline.org/news/vatican/pope-francis-suggests-people-have-moral-obligation-take-coronavirus-vaccine">

column1: Can I have the vaccine as a Catholic?
column3: The vaccine is approved by the Catholic church
column4: The Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith announced in a statement that all vaccinations recognized as clinically safe and effective can be used in good conscience 💜 🙏 .

column1: Can I have the vaccine if I'm allergic to penicillin?
column3: The vaccine is safe for people with penicillin allergies
column4: All of the available vaccines are safe even if you are allergic to penicillin ✅.

column1: Can I meet in groups after I'm vaccinated?
column3: You can meet fully vaccinated individuals when vaccinated
column4: In general, you can meet in groups after you are vaccinated unless you are at high risk for COVID-19. If traveling before doing so, it's important to take other safety precautions, like masking! 🦠 . <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/coronavirus/covid19-safety-tips-for-families">

column1: Can I meet in groups after I'm vaccinated?
column3: You can meet fully vaccinated individuals when vaccinated
column4: You can meet in groups after you are vaccinated! However, you should consider wearing your mask 😷 and practicing social distancing if around high-risk individuals or in a crowded area. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html">

column1: Can I still get COVID even after being vaccinated?
column3: You can still get COVID even after being vaccinated
column4: While the vaccines are very effective, there is a small chance you could contract COVID-19 after getting vaccinated. Booster shots are recommended to maintain your immunity against the virus for longer. If you have COVID-19 symptoms, please get tested as soon as possible 🏥✅.

column1: Can I still get COVID even after being vaccinated?
column3: You can still get COVID even after being vaccinated
column4: The vaccines are highly effective, but there's a chance you could still get COVID-19 after being vaccinated 🩹. To stay safe, especially againts the new variants of the virus, get your booster shot as soon as you can! Remember to get tested ASAP if you have symptoms of COVID-19 🏥.

column1: Can I take a pain reliever when I get vaccinated?
column3: It is okay to take one pain relievers after vaccination
column4: Adults and children may take an over-the-counter pain reliever if they have uncomfortable side effects after vaccination. The CDC recommends you don't take one prior to vaccination🩹. <LINK|“Learn more here!” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect.html”>

column1: Can I take a pain reliever when I get vaccinated?
column3: It is okay to take one pain relievers after vaccination
column4: The CDC and the World Health Organization recommend adults and children don't use pain relievers before getting a vaccine, but they're okay afterwards✅. <LINK|“Learn more here!” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect.html”>

column1: Can I take a pain reliever when I get vaccinated?
column3: It is okay to take one pain relievers after vaccination
column4: Adults and children should avoid pain relief medications before getting the COVID-19 vaccine, but they are fine to take after ✅! <LINK|“Learn more here!” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect.html”>

column1: Can my child get the booster?
column3: Children above 5 can now get the booster
column4: Kids 6 months and older can receive the updated (bivalent) booster vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which target Omicron variants. For Pfizer, the vaccine is available as a third dose in the primary series for kids 6 months to 4 years. For Moderna, the vaccine is administered as a booster at least two months after completion of the primary series for kids 6 months to 5 years. ✅ Learn more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html">

column1: Can my child get the booster?
column3: Children above 5 can now get the booster
column4: With a surge in cases in children due to new emerging variants, the CDC recommends boosters for children above the ages of 5. Kids 6+ months can receive the updated (bivalent) booster vaccine, which targets Omicron strains, at least 2 months after completing their last dose (Moderna) or as the final dose in their primary series (Pfizer). Learn more about these vaccines <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html">

column1: Can my child get the booster?
column3: Children above 5 can now get the booster
column4: The FDA authorized and the CDC recommended the updated (bivalent) boosters for children 6+ months. 👶  This age group can receive the updated (bivalent) booster vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which target Omicron strains, at least 2 months after completing their last dose or as the final dose in their primary series. The data shows that the potential benefits of boosters for children 6+ months outweighs the known risks and provides continued protection against COVID-19. ✅ Read more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html">

column1: Can my infant or child get a Moderna vaccine?

column1: Can my infant or child get a Moderna vaccine?
column3: Children under 5 are eligible for a Moderna vaccine
column4: The Moderna vaccine (and bivalent booster) has been recommended by the CDC  for children 6 months and older. 💉 The vaccine has been proven to be safe and effective in children from 6 months of age. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children” >

column3: Children under 5 are eligible for a Moderna vaccine

Talk to your healthcare provider to understand the best time to get your infant or child vaccinated. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children” >

column1: Can my kids go back to school without a vaccine?
column3: A child needing a vaccine to go to school will depend on the state
column4: This decision is up to each state. Check with your local health department to determine whether or not your child will need a COVID-19 vaccine to go to school✅.

column1: Can my kids go back to school without a vaccine?
column3: A child needing a vaccine to go to school will depend on the state
column4: Check out your school district or university policies📄to see if they require a COVID-19 vaccine to return to school!

column1: Can my kids go back to school without a vaccine?
column3: A child needing a vaccine to go to school will depend on the state
column4: Right now, elementary, middle, and high school students are not required to get the COVID-19 vaccine before returning to school. column1: Can my kids go back to school without a vaccine?
column3: A child needing a vaccine to go to school will depend on the state
column4: This depends on your state and may change in the coming months, so check with your school district to learn more as school starts again this fall 📄✅.

column1: Can my kids go back to school without a vaccine?

column4: The vaccines have different wait times between doses 📅. Check with your health provider for the dosing schedule of your particular vaccine, and make sure your second dose is the same vaccine brand as your first dose! 🏥✅  The CDC also recommends a booster shot for individuals 6 months or older to improve protection against the newer variants of the virus, but your booster does not need to be the same brand as your primary vaccine. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/covid-19-vaccines-us.html" >

column1: How long do I have to wait between doses?
column3: It depends on the vaccine
column4: For most ages, you will need 2 shots to get substantial protection for three of the vaccines 🦺. Pfizer and Novavax requires 3 weeks between doses, Moderna requires 4 weeks, and the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is only one dose. However, if you're a healthy individual between the ages 12 and 65, you can have an interval of 3 to 8 weeks between your first and second Pfizer/Moderna dose.  <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/covid-19-vaccines-us.html" >

column1: How long does the immunity from the vaccine last?
column3: Protection lasts at least 4 months
column4: Researchers are still trying to understand exactly how long a vaccine’s protection will last against different variants, but studies have shown that immunity begins to wane 6 months post vaccination. 📅✅ This number varies from one person to another depending on factors like age and other underlying comorbidities. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/how-long-will-coronavirus-vaccine-last" > Find informational videos on COVID-19 vaccination <LINK | "here!" | "https://www.greaterthancovid.org/theconversation/" >

column1: How long does the immunity from the vaccine last?
column3: Protection lasts at least 4 months
column4: Immunity from your primary vaccination series begins to wane 6 months after your second dose of vaccination. An additional booster shot is recommended for better protection, especially against the newer variants of the virus. 🦠<LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/how-long-will-coronavirus-vaccine-last" > Find informational videos on COVID-19 vaccination <LINK | "here!" | "https://www.greaterthancovid.org/theconversation/" >

column1: How long until I will be protected after taking the vaccine?
column3: Fully immunity takes a few weeks
column4: It takes a few weeks for your body to begin producing antibodies after any vaccination 🩹. Vaccines start to have a partial effect about 12 days after the first dose, but their full protective effect starts 14 days after the last dose of the series 📅 . <LINK | “Check out the CDC for more info.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”>

column1: How long until I will be protected after taking the vaccine?
column3: Fully immunity takes a few weeks
column4: With all three vaccines, your immunity to COVID-19 will build over a few weeks after immunization 🩹. Protection usually begins around 2 weeks after your second or final dose, and this is when you are considered fully vaccinated 📅 ✔.  <LINK | “Check out the CDC for more info.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”>

column1: How long until I will be protected after taking the vaccine?
column3: Fully immunity takes a few weeks
column4: Generally, protection from the virus starts 12-14 days from immunization 📅 . This is because your immune system needs to generate a response, and people’s immune systems can vary ✔.  <LINK | “Check out the CDC for more info.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”>

column1: How many boosters can I get?
column3: The number of booster vaccines depends on age
column4: The recommended number of boosters depends on your age and whether you are immunocompromised. In general, those who are 12+ and are not immunocompromised can receive two total boosters: the original booster and the updated booster (at least two months after their original booster shot) ✅. Click <LINK | “here” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”> to see if you're eligible for the new booster.

column1: How many doses do I need?
column3: Vaccines require 1 or 2 doses
column4: Pfizer-BioNTech and Novavax requires two doses 3-8 weeks apart and Moderna requires two doses 4-8 weeks apart. Apart from these primary vaccination(s), a booster shot is recommended 5 months after the Pfizer (for individuals 12 and older) or Moderna (for individuals 18 and older) series. 🦺🌞 <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines.html" >

column1: How many doses does my child under 5 need?
column3: The number of doses for your infant or child depends on the make of the vaccine
column4: The number of doses your child needs depends on the vaccine manufacturer. For Pfizer-BioNTech, there are three shots in total. The first two doses are administered 3-8 weeks apart and the booster dose is given at least two months after the second dose. Moderna has two shots in its series, administered 4-8 weeks apart. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children”>

column1: How many doses does my child under 5 need?
column3: The number of doses for your infant or child depends on the make of the vaccine
column4: Two vaccines have been authorized for children under 5. 👶✅ Pfizer-BioNTech has 3 shots in its series for children 6 months – 4 years and the Moderna vaccine has 2 shots in its series for children 6 months – 5 years. Both vaccines are known to confer protection against severe disease due to COVID-19 in children. Learn more about the dosing schedule < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children”>

column1: How many doses does my child under 5 need?
column3: The number of doses for your infant or child depends on the make of the vaccine

Both Pfizer and Moderna vaccines offers protection against the risk of severe disease due to COVID-19, but they cannot be mixed! Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children”>

column1: What does bivalent mean?
column3: The bivalent boosters contain two types of the virus
column4: The Pfizer and Moderna bivalent boosters target two types of the virus that causes COVID-19: the original strain from 2020 and Omicron subvariants. These boosters work the same way as the original Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, but they give you added protection against Omicron-specific variants. 💪 Click <LINK | “here” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”> to see if you're eligible for the new booster.

column1: What does bivalent mean?
column3: The bivalent boosters contain two types of the virus
column4: The bivalent boosters target two strains of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The original Pfizer and Moderna boosters were updated to provide protection against the original strain AND Omicron-specific strains of the virus. 💪 This means you will have expanded protection against COVID-19.  Click <LINK | “here” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”> to see if you're eligible for the new booster.

column1: What does vaccine efficacy mean?
column3: Efficacy is how well it performs in clinical trials
column4: Vaccine efficacy refers to how well the vaccine performs in a carefully controlled trial, whereas effectiveness describes its performance in the real world ✅🌐. <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.gavi.org/vaccineswork/what-difference-between-efficacy-and-effectiveness”>

column1: What does vaccine efficacy mean?
column3: Efficacy is how well it performs in clinical trials
column4: Vaccine efficacy is determined by the performance of the vaccine under ideal and controlled circumstances 🔬. Effectiveness refers to its performance in uncontrolled, real-world conditions 🌐. <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.gavi.org/vaccineswork/what-difference-between-efficacy-and-effectiveness”>

column1: What happens if there is a COVID-19 case at my child’s school?
column3: The local school district will determine protocol for a COVID-19 case at your child's school
column4: I wish I could help people with the protocol for COVID-19 at a local school. 🤔 Unfortunately, I can only suggest that people check with their local school district to learn about this.  <LINK | “Learn more from the CDC.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/parent-faqs.html”>

column1: What if I still get infected even after receiving the vaccine?
column3: Getting sick after getting vaccinated means less severe illness
column4: If you get COVID-19 after vaccination, your symptoms are likely to be less serious ✅. You can protect yourself and family members by wearing a mask when around people who haven't gotten a vaccine yet 😷. <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/effectiveness/why-measure-effectiveness/breakthrough-cases.html”>

column1: What if I still get infected even after receiving the vaccine?
column3: Getting sick after getting vaccinated means less severe illness
column4: Several trials have shown that vaccination greatly reduces your risk of getting symptomatic COVID-19, and if you do get infected, you're less likely to have severe disease 👏🙏.  <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/effectiveness/why-measure-effectiveness/breakthrough-cases.html”>

column1: What if I've been treated with convalescent plasma?
column3: Take the vaccine 90 days after convalescent plasma treatment
column4: It is recommended that you still get vaccinated even if you've been treated with convalescent plasma. However, you should wait 90 days after treatment to ensure vaccine effectiveness 📅✅. <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.mayoclinic.org/coronavirus-covid-19/vaccine-if-already-had-covid”>

column1: What if I've been treated with convalescent plasma?
column3: Take the vaccine 90 days after convalescent plasma treatment
column4: You should defer your vaccine for at least 90 days after plasma treatment to ensure vaccine effectiveness to protect you from COVID-19 📅✅.

column1: What if I've been treated with convalescent plasma?
column3: Take the vaccine 90 days after convalescent plasma treatment
column4: You can get vaccinated, but be sure to wait at least 90 days 📅 after you received convalescent plasma to maximize how protected you are against COVID-19 ✅! <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.mayoclinic.org/coronavirus-covid-19/vaccine-if-already-had-covid”>

column1: What if I've been treated with monoclonal antibodies?
column3: Take the vaccine 90 days after monoclonal antibody treatment
column4: If the monoclonal antibodies were for COVID-19, then wait 90 days before getting vaccinated 📅. If the monoclonal antibodies were for something else, then there is no need to wait 👏. <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.cms.gov/monoclonal”>

column1: What if I've been treated with monoclonal antibodies?
column3: Take the vaccine 90 days after monoclonal antibody treatment
column4: The CDC recommends that you wait at least 90 days after treatment to get vaccinated. This is to make sure your treatment does not interfere with any vaccine-induced immune responses ✅.  <LINK | “Learn more!” | “https://www.cms.gov/monoclonal”>

column1: What is breakthrough infection?
column3: Vaccinated individuals can still get infected with COVID - 19
column4: Infection of a fully vaccinated individual is termed as ‘breakthrough’ infection. This can occur since no vaccine is 100% effective – especially against new variants that emerge. Fully vaccinated people with a breakthrough infection are less likely to develop serious illness than those who are unvaccinated and get COVID-19. 💉 <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/effectiveness/why-measure-effectiveness/breakthrough-cases.html">

column1: What is breakthrough infection?
column3: Vaccinated individuals can still get infected with COVID - 19
column4: If you catch COVID-19 even after being fully vaccinated, the infection is called a ‘breakthrough’ infection. This is expected to occur since like all other vaccines, COVID – 19 vaccines are not 100% effective. Thankfully, when breakthrough infections occur the symptoms are not as severe and are individuals are less likely to be hospitalized as compared to unvaccinated people. 💉 <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/effectiveness/why-measure-effectiveness/breakthrough-cases.html">

column1: What is breakthrough infection?
column3: Vaccinated individuals can still get infected with COVID - 19
column4: All COVID-19 vaccines offer protection against severe illness and death. 💉However, it is possible to be infected with COVID – 19 even if you’re up to date with your vaccinations. The great news is that even if you get infected after being vaccinated, the risk of infection, hospitalization, and death are all much lower in vaccinated compared to unvaccinated people. Vaccination remains the best way to stay safe. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/effectiveness/why-measure-effectiveness/breakthrough-cases.html">

column1: What is COVID?
column3: COVID-19 is a serious viral illness
column4: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a new coronavirus not previously seen in humans 🦠. Though COVID-19 disease is mild in most people who have it, it can cause severe illness or death and it spreads very easily from person-to-person, which is why it is crucial to get vaccinated against COVID-19 🩹. <LINK | “Learn about prevention, symptoms, testing, vaccines, and more from the CDC.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html”>

column1: What is COVID?
column3: COVID-19 is a serious viral illness
column4: COVID-19 is a disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus 🦠. It can be extremely dangerous and result in hospitalization or death for some folks 🏥. The best way to protect yourself and your loved ones is by getting vaccinated. <LINK | “Learn about prevention, symptoms, testing, vaccines, and more from the CDC.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html”>

column1: What is COVID?

While most people experience mild COVID-19, others can develop serious or fatal illness. <LINK | “Learn about prevention, symptoms, testing, vaccines, and more from the CDC.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html”>

column1: What is in the vaccine?
column3: Vaccine ingredients are safe and effective
column4: There are many different types of vaccines and each has different components. All vaccines have a molecule that teaches your immune system to recognize and fight the COVID-19 virus ✅. Learn more about the approved COVID-19 vaccines <LINK | "here." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/how-they-work.html" >

column1: What is in the vaccine?
column3: Vaccine ingredients are safe and effective
column4: Each type of vaccine has different components. Some components work to transport the vaccine in your body, some help your body recognize COVID-19, and some teach your immune system how to fight COVID-19 🤔✅. <LINK | "Learn more here." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/how-they-work.html" >

column1: What is Ivermectin?
column3: Ivermectin should not be used to treat COVID
column4: In the US, Ivermectin is used to treat some parasitic worms and external parasites. It cannot treat or prevent COVID-19. You should only take medicine prescribed by your health care provider and acquired from a legitimate source to treat COVID-19. <LINK | “Learn more.” | “https://www.fda.gov/animal-veterinary/product-safety-information/faq-covid-19-and-ivermectin-intended-animals”>

column1: What is Ivermectin?
column3: Ivermectin should not be used to treat COVID
column4: Ivermectin is most often used to treat or prevent parasites in animals and humans. It has not been approved to prevent or treat COVID-19 and is dangerous to take in large doses. <LINK | “Learn more.” | “https://www.fda.gov/animal-veterinary/product-safety-information/faq-covid-19-and-ivermectin-intended-animals”>

column1: What is Ivermectin?
column3: Ivermectin should not be used to treat COVID
column4: Ivermectin is most often used to treat or prevent parasites in animals and humans and people should NOT take it to prevent or treat COVID-19. The best way to prevent COVID-19 is by getting vaccinated. <LINK | “Learn more here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/animal-veterinary/product-safety-information/faq-covid-19-and-ivermectin-intended-animals”>

column1: What is mRNA?
column3: mRNA is safe and effective
column4: mRNA helps give your body the instructions for how to find and fight the virus 📄. mRNA vaccines have been in development for many years and have been proven to be safe and effective against COVID-19 🙏. <LINK | "Learn more here." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/mrna.html" >

column1: What is mRNA?
column3: mRNA is safe and effective
column4: mRNA is like giving your body the instructions for how to find and fight the virus 📃. mRNA has been researched for vaccines for many years and it doesn't cause any changes to your DNA ✅. <LINK | "Learn more here." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/mrna.html" >

column1: What is Paxlovid?
column3: Paxlovid is an investigational new drug
column4: Paxlovid is an oral antiviral therapy from Pfizer that may be prescribed by your healthcare provider in some instances if you have been diagnosed with mild to moderate COVID-19 infection. Studies have shown it may reduce progression to severe disease in persons at risk. It is an investigational drug that has received emergency use authorization from the FDA. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/treatments-for-severe-illness.html” >

column1: What is Paxlovid?
column3: Paxlovid is an investigational new drug
column4: Pfizer’s Paxlovid is an investigational antiviral drug prescribed in some instances when a patient tests positive for COVID-19. There are limited data on its safety and efficacy, but it is believed to slow down the replication of the virus in the body and reduces risk of severe disease. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/treatments-for-severe-illness.html” >

column1: What is the difference between FDA authorization and approval?
column3: Authorization and approval differ for many reasons
column4: For an FDA emergency use authorization, evidence must show that a vaccine is safe and that it reduces disease. Vaccines are not used if these two requirements are not met. Full FDA approval comes later when additional data is available on things like how long protection lasts, how effective it is across a population, and rate of any rarer events. 📅 The Pfizer vaccine has received full FDA approval for those 16+ and Moderna has received full approval for adults. The Novavax vaccine have received emergency use authorization. <LINK | “Learn more here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/emergency-use-authorization-vaccines-explained”>

column1: What is the difference between FDA authorization and approval?
column3: Authorization and approval differ for many reasons
column4: Emergency use authorization allows the FDA to use medicines right away if they are proven safe and effective at reducing disease. In a public health emergency, this allows us to respond more quickly. ✅  Approval is a slower process, which comes when we have additional information about a medicine or vaccine. The Pfizer vaccine has received full FDA approval for those 16+ and Moderna has received full approval for adults. The Novavax vaccine has received emergency use authorization. <LINK | “Read more.” | “https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/emergency-use-authorization-vaccines-explained”>

column1: What is the difference between FDA authorization and approval?
column3: Authorization and approval differ for many reasons
column4: The main difference between FDA authorization and approval is that FDA authorization requires evidence that a vaccine is safe and effective at reducing disease, while approval requires much more information on things like how long protecion lasts, how effective it is across a population, and rate of any rarer events. The authorization process allows us to respond more quickly in a public health emergency while still ensuring safety. The Pfizer vaccine has received full FDA approval for those 16+ and Moderna has received full approval for adults. The Novavax vaccine has received emergency use authorization.  <LINK | “Read more.” | “https://www.fda.gov/vaccines-blood-biologics/vaccines/emergency-use-authorization-vaccines-explained”>

column1: What is the difference between mRNA and viral vector vaccines?
column3: Both mRNA and viral vector vaccines are safe and effective
column4: Both types of vaccines deliver information to your cells, but differ in how they do this. No matter what, this information breaks down and can't be incorporated into your genetic code 📄✅. <LINK|"Check this out to learn more."|"https://fb.watch/atA9GhpZgy/">

column1: What is the difference between mRNA and viral vector vaccines?
column3: Both mRNA and viral vector vaccines are safe and effective
column4: mRNA vaccines—Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines—provide genetic instructions for making viral proteins without injecting any virus into your body. Viral vector vaccines—Novavax or Johnson & Johnson vaccines—use a harmless virus to deliver the instructions to your body 📄. <LINK|"Check this out to learn more."|"https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/different-types-of-covid-19-vaccines/art-20506465">

column1: What is the difference between quarantine and isolation?
column3: Quarantine and isolation differ based on exposure or infection
column4: Quarantine occurs when you may have been exposed to the virus,🦠 but isolation occurs when you have been infected with the virus (regardless of whether you have symptoms). <LINK | “Learn more here.” | “https://www.hhs.gov/answers/public-health-and-safety/what-is-the-difference-between-isolation-and-quarantine/index.html”>

column1: What is the difference between quarantine and isolation?
column3: Quarantine and isolation differ based on exposure or infection
column4: Quarantine is required when you have been exposed to the virus, but isolation separates people with a contagious disease (regardless of whether you have symptoms) from people who are not sick. <LINK | “Learn more here.” | “https://www.hhs.gov/answers/public-health-and-safety/what-is-the-difference-between-isolation-and-quarantine/index.html”>

column1: What is the difference between the third shot and a booster shot?
column3: Booster is given to those with full protection already
column4: A third (additional) shot 🩹is given to those who are moderately to severely immunocompromised because they were unlikely to achieve full protection after their original vaccination. A booster shot is designed to help people maintain immunity after it begins to wane, and also helps your body fight the highly transmissible Omicron variants. <LINK | “Learn more.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”>

column1: What is the difference between the third shot and a booster shot?
column3: Booster is given to those with full protection already
column4: A third (additional) shot 🩹is given to those who are moderately to severely immunocompromised because they were unlikely to achieve full protection after their original vaccination. A booster shot is designed to help people maintain immunity after it begins to wane. New data shows that booster also provides better protection against Omicron and other variants than the primary series alone.  <LINK | “Learn more.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html”>

column1: What is the Moderna vaccine?
column3: The Moderna vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine
column4: The Moderna vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine. It requires 2 doses (given 28 days apart). People may experience some side effects after getting it, but the vaccine is highly effective at protecting against COVID-19 and its variants. It has received full FDA approval for use in adults. <LINK | "Learn more from the CDC." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html">

column1: What is the Moderna vaccine?
column3: The Moderna vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine
column4: The Moderna vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine. It uses mRNA to teach your body how to fight COVID-19 if you get infected. The vaccine is extremely safe and effective, so you can feel good about getting it. Anyone 6 months and older can get it. It has received full FDA approval for use in adults.

column1: What is the Moderna vaccine?
column3: The Moderna vaccine is a COVID-19 vaccine
column4: The Moderna vaccine is one of four COVID-19 vaccines authorized in the US. It is extremely safe and effective at preventing COVID-19 and is recommended for people 6 months and older. It has received full FDA approval for use in adults. <LINK | "Learn more from the CDC." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/Moderna.html">

column1: What is the Novavax vaccine?
column3: Novavax is an FDA-approved vaccine for COVID-19
column4: Novavax is one of the four FDA authorized vaccines for COVID-19 in the US for adults aged 12 and older. 💉 It consists of two doses given 3 – 8 weeks apart. <LINK | “Read more here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-emergency-use-novavax-covid-19-vaccine-adjuvanted”>

column1: What is the Novavax vaccine?
column3: Novavax is an FDA-approved vaccine for COVID-19
column4: Novavax’s COVID – 19 vaccine is a protein -based vaccine, similar to other existing approved vaccines. 💉 It has been approved for adults 12 years and older and needs two doses administered 3 to 8 weeks apart.<LINK | “Learn more here.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-emergency-use-novavax-covid-19-vaccine-adjuvanted”>

column1: What is the Novavax vaccine?
column3: Novavax is an FDA-approved vaccine for COVID-19
column4: Novavax is one of the FDA authorized vaccines in the US. It was developed using a traditional protein-based approach, like that used in tetanus, HPV and hepatitis B vaccines.  Novavax is now approved for adults 12 years and above. 💪 <LINK | “Learn more.” | “https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-emergency-use-novavax-covid-19-vaccine-adjuvanted”>

column1: What is the Omicron variant?
column3: There is not much known about the Omicron variant
column4: Omicron is the dominant variant of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, in the United States. Experts consider the variant highly transmissble and contagious, but believe it may cause less severe disease than other variants. The CDC will continue monitoring Omicron and other variants  ✅. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/variants/index.html” >

column1: What is the Omicron variant?
column3: There is not much known about the Omicron variant
column4: Omicron is another variant of the virus that causes COVID-19; it is responsible for more than 90% of new COVID-19 infections in the United States. Since the virus was discovered in late 2021, scientists are still learning about its spread and severity. Early studies suggest the virus is highly contagious, but may cause less severe disease. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/variants/index.html” >

column1: What is the Omicron variant?
column3: There is not much known about the Omicron variant
column4: Omicron is another mutation of the virus that causes COVID-19. Studies are underway to learn more about Omicron, however, early indications suggest Omicron spreads faster than other variants and may cause less severe disease. Additionally, the hospitalization or even death is reduced with boosters and vaccinations. Learn more < LINK | “here.” | “https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/variants/index.html” >

column1: What mask should I be wearing?
column3: You should wear n95 and kn95 masks
column4: N95 or KN95 masks provide the best protection, but layered cloth masks or procedure masks can sometimes be used too. 😷 When choosing a mask, find one that fits snugly over your nose, mouth and chin, and that you will wear consistently. Masking helps to keep ourselves and our communities safe against COVID-19. 🌞💜 Learn more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/types-of-masks.html">

column1: What mask should I be wearing?
column3: You should wear n95 and kn95 masks
column4: CDC recommends everyone 2 years or older to mask up, especially in crowded indoor settings. It is important for your mask to fit snugly over your nose, mouth and chin. The N95 or KN95 masks provide the best protection, but layered cloth and disposable masks provide protection too. 😷 Learn more <LINK | “here.” | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/types-of-masks.html">

column1: When can I go back to normal life?
column3: We need to achieve heard immunity to go back to normal
column4: Once 14 days have passed from your completed vaccine course, you can again do the activities you did prior to the pandemic, but be mindful of the local regulations and guidelines ✅📄. <LINK|"Learn more."|"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html">

column1: When can I go back to normal life?
column3: We need to achieve heard immunity to go back to normal
column4: Normal life can return once you are fully vaccinated! Complete vaccination occurs 14 days after you receive the final dose in your vaccine series. Just be mindful of local regulations and guidelines when returning to normal life ✅🌞. <LINK|"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html">

column1: When can I go back to normal life?
column3: We need to achieve heard immunity to go back to normal
column4: The fastest way we will return to normal is by getting vaccinated. Encourage your family and friends to do the same so we can stop COVID-19 💜🙏 . <LINK|"Learn more."|"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html">

column1: Where are we required to wear masks now?
column3: Masks are required in certain settings
column4: People over 2 years old should wear a mask 😷 when indoors in a public place and in crowded areas. Masking is not required on public transportation, including airplanes, but the CDC continues to recommend masking in indoor public transportation settings. CDC masking recommendations may also depend on the COVID community transmission levels of your county. <LINK | "Learn more." | "https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/about-face-coverings.html">

column1: Which one of the vaccines should I take?
column2: Some vaccines are better than others
